sequence.title: Facts vs Opinion + Bias Starter
objectives: Differentiate fact vs opinion in current news
Identify bias and techniques in headlines

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning to distinguish fact, opinion and bias in media.
successCriteria: I can label statements as fact/opinion with reasons
I can name one bias technique used in a headline

steps: Hook: two contrasting headlines; quick decide ‘fact/opinion’ and why.
Pairs annotate a mixed set; highlight claims, evidence, emotive language.
Whole class: build a mini ‘bias bingo’ list for future spotting.
sequence.assessment: Exit ticket: 1 fact claim + 1 opinion claim with justification.
teacherTips: Differentiation: provide sentence starters for justifications.
Formative: cold-call a few pairs to model precise language.

sequence.title: News Diet Challenge (48-hour)
objectives: Plan one improvement to balance sources

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning to reflect on the diversity and reliability of our news sources.
successCriteria: I can categorise sources by type and reliability
I can name one concrete change to improve my news diet

steps: Students track sources for 48h.
Pairs swap logs, classify and suggest one improvement.
Debrief: share common patterns and quick wins.
sequence.assessment: Collect logs; check categorisation + improvement suggestion.
teacherTips: ELL support: picture icons for source types.

sequence.title: Frayer Model: Party Ideology
objectives: Define key ideological terms and apply with examples

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning to describe and compare party ideologies.
successCriteria: I can complete a Frayer with clear examples/non-examples
I can contrast two parties on one policy area

steps: Assign terms/parties to groups; complete Frayer.
Gallery walk with ‘two stars and a wish’.
Class builds a comparative table for one policy (e.g., climate).
sequence.assessment: Collect Frayers; check accuracy and evidence use.

sequence.title: How a Bill Becomes Law – Role-Play
objectives: Experience debate, amendment and voting processes

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning the stages of federal law-making.
successCriteria: I can name the main stages and what happens at each
I can describe the purpose of amendments and committees

steps: Assign roles (Speaker/President, Govt/Opposition, Crossbench, Clerks, Whips, Media).
Run through readings, debate, optional committee, amendments, vote.
Debrief: map our simulation to the official process.
sequence.assessment: Quick-write: which stage most influences outcomes and why?
teacherTips: Timebox speeches; use traffic-light cards to manage talk time.

sequence.title: Bridge: From Bill Process → Policy Trade-offs (Cards Against Calamity)
objectives: Connect legislative steps to real policy trade-offs

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning how competing priorities shape policy outcomes.
successCriteria: I can justify a policy choice with stakeholder evidence
I can explain how an amendment could shift outcomes

steps: Teams play a shortened round focused on one issue.
Each decision logged with ‘who benefits / who loses / evidence’.
Share-out: connect decisions to potential legislative amendments.
sequence.assessment: Collect decision logs; check justified reasoning.
teacherTips: Assign rotating role: ‘evidence officer’ to cite sources.

sequence.title: Mock Hearing: Courts Support Democracy
objectives: Explain rule of law and judicial independence

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning how courts ensure fairness in a democracy.
successCriteria: I can describe roles in a hearing
I can use the term ‘judicial independence’ correctly

steps: Groups stage a short hearing with set roles.
Observers complete fairness/due-process checklist.
Compare outcomes; discuss consistency and appeals.
sequence.assessment: Reflection paragraph on fairness and due process.
teacherTips: Offer simplified scripts for EAL/D students.

sequence.title: Petition & Lobby Plan (Local Issue)
objectives: Map an issue, stakeholders and lawful action pathway
Draft a persuasive petition and outreach plan

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning to plan a lawful, effective avenue for change.
successCriteria: I can write a clear ‘ask’ with reasons and evidence
I can identify decision-makers and next steps

steps: Choose a local issue; map stakeholders/decision-makers.
Draft petition text (clear ask, reasons, evidence).
Plan outreach (meetings/letters/social media etiquette).
sequence.assessment: Submit a 1-page plan with SMART next steps.
teacherTips: Model a sample paragraph using TEAL/PEEL.

sequence.title: Civics Inquiry (Student Choice Product)
objectives: Investigate a civics issue and present evidence-based recommendations

visibleLearning.learningIntentions: We are learning to investigate and communicate a civics issue using evidence.
successCriteria: I can formulate a guiding question
I can evaluate sources for reliability and bias

steps: Define guiding question aligned to content descriptors.
Collect/evaluate sources; track evidence.
Present via report, video, podcast, **Minecraft build**, infographic or live talk.
sequence.assessment: Rubric aligned to ACARA Y9 Civics & Citizenship.
teacherTips: Offer conferencing checkpoints; provide exemplars for each mode.
